description.en: The course is taught in lecture and seminar forms. For lectures, students are required to do the assigned required readings before coming to class. Seminars are focused on students' ability to comprehend the required reading materials, discuss, and evaluate a number of questions that are posed prior to each seminar. Whereas group presentations and final written essay are designed for students to develop and show their ability to engage in group work and analyse, develop, and create novel arguments, respectively.
description.et: Kursust õpetatakse loengu- ja seminarivormis. Loengute jaoks on üliõpilased kohustatud enne tundi tulekut sooritama määratud kohustuslikud lugemised. Seminarid keskenduvad õpilaste võimele mõista vajalikku lugemismaterjali, arutada ja hinnata mitmeid küsimusi, mis enne iga seminari esitatakse. Rühmaesitlused ja lõplik kirjalik essee on mõeldud selleks, et õpilased saaksid arendada ja näidata oma võimet rühmatöös osaleda ning vastavalt analüüsida, arendada ja luua uudseid argumente.

objectives.en: The course aims to introduce students to concepts and theories of self-determination and secession. It, furthermore, attempts to relate these concepts, by use of empirical record, to the process of state creation in different historical periods, with a particular focus on the contemporary one. Lastly, the course aims to disentangle the theories and practices of state recognition in world politics.
objectives.et: Kursuse eesmärk on tutvustada õpilastele enesemääramise ja eraldumise mõisteid ja teooriaid. Lisaks proovib see empiirilisi andmeid kasutades seostada neid mõisteid riigi loomise protsessiga erinevatel ajalooperioodidel, keskendudes eelkõige tänapäevale. Lõpetuseks on kursuse eesmärk lahti harutada riigi tunnustamise teooriad ja praktikad maailmapoliitikas.

learning_outcomes.en: By the end of the course students will be able to:
Demonstrate a solid understanding of the creation and expansion of the international society of states;
learning_outcomes.et: Demonstreerida kindlat arusaamist riikide rahvusvahelise ühiskonna loomisest ja laienemisest;

learning_outcomes.en: Critically analyze notions of self-determination and secession in light of the (non)creation of states in the international system;
learning_outcomes.et: Kriitiliselt analüüsida enesemääramise ja eraldumise mõisteid riikide (mitte)loomise valguses rahvusvahelises süsteemis;

learning_outcomes.en: Interpret the multiple intricacies of state and government (non)recognition in world politics;
learning_outcomes.et: Tõlgendada riigi ja valitsuse (mitte)tunnustamise keerukust maailmapoliitikas;

learning_outcomes.en: Interpret the historical and contemporary secessionist and self-determination movements;
learning_outcomes.et: Tõlgendada ajaloolist ja kaasaegset separatistlikku ja enesemääramisliikumist;

learning_outcomes.en: Analyze the aims, goals, and strategies that different groups of people attempt, and have attempted, to use in promoting their self-determination claims and establishing their states;
learning_outcomes.et: Analüüsida eesmärke ja strateegiaid, mida erinevad inimrühmad püüavad ja on püüdnud kasutada oma enesemääramisnõuete edendamisel ja oma seisundite kehtestamisel;

description.et: Brief learning diaries (individual): Students are expected to do the required weekly readings (on average 2 pieces a week) before coming to class. Students are expected to submit brief learning diaries on the required weekly readings 24 hours before the scheduled class. [If the class happens to be scheduled on Mondays and students don't want to work on Sundays or weekends, they must plan this beforehand so long as the diaries get submitted 24 hours before class]. Each weekly learning diary consists of a maximum 200 words. For the learning diaries, students will be asked to focus on (i) what they have found challenging or confusing from the readings; (i) what they have found interesting that they have learned from the readings; and/or (iii) pose a question they may have from the readings. Each weekly submission is worth 2 points of the final grade, with 15 submissions amounting to 30 points of the final grade. Missing the deadline will give students zero points; submitting a general, unrelated, or superficial comment on the diaries will give them 1 point; submitting meaningful and closely related to the readings learning diaries will grant them the maximum 2 points. Further details will be provided and communicated during the first meeting, and the online submission form will be explained.

Case study analysis (in groups): students will have to submit a written analysis that has to include at least two cases under the subject of the course. The assignment consists of a written work of a maximum of 1,200 words, in groups [size of groups TBD]. Further details will be provided and communicated during the first meeting, but also prior to the assignment deadline which shall be due sometime in the second half of the semester (the exact date TBD). The case study analysis is worth 25 points of the final grade.

Final written essay (individual): students are expected to conduct independent research for the final written assignment in each topic/theme/question that touches upon specific or broader aspects course's. They shall be able to demonstrate that they can ask a question about an issue, and/or engage in a debate about the broader issues related to the course. Further details will be provided and communicated during the first meeting, but also prior to the assignment deadline which shall be due sometime after all the sessions will have been completed (the exact date TBD). The final written essay will be worth 45 points of the final grade.

grade_preconditions.et:
To be eligible for the final grade, students are expected 

To attend at least 80% of the lectures and seminars - combined. 

To meet the total calculated weighted grade 51 or above on all the assignments.

grade_evaluation.et:
Learning diaries (individual): 30% of the final grade 

Case study analysis (group): 25% of the final grade 

Final essay (individual): 45% of the final grade
